this is how I saw the ocean it's just a

I saw Hills and

my characters are my lead characters a

Predator uh image he's uh kind of just

story on the census of marine life and
that was a lot of fun because as most of
you know it's a real project we've heard
about it um but it was a chance for me
to introduce readers to to a lot of

as a census taker he goes down and he
meets this famous angler
fish then he meets the yeti crab famous

the Dumbo octopus which looks so much
like a cartoon in real life that I
really didn't have to change a thing
when I drew it I did another story on
Marine debris I was speaking to a lot of
my friends in the conservation business
and they
I asked him so what's what's one issue
you would like everyone to know more
about and they they said or this one
friend of mine said I've got one word
for you
plastic um and I told him well I need
something a little sexier than that
plastic just is not going to do it we
sort of worked things out he wanted me
to use words like polyvinyl chloride
which just doesn't really work in voice
balloons very well I couldn't fit them
in so what I did was I made it an
adventure strip basically this bottle
travels a long way what I'm trying to
tell readers is that plastic doesn't
really go away it just continues to wash
down stream and a lot of it ends up
washing into the ocean um which is a
great story if you attach a couple
characters to it especially if they
can't stand each other like these
two so uh I sent them to Boise
Idaho where they uh dropped a plastic
bottle into the Boise sewer system and
it ended up in the Boise
River and then onto the Columbia River
and then to the mouth of the Columbia in
to the Pacific Ocean and then onto this
place called the Great Pacific Garbage
Patch which is this giant pacific gy in
the North Pacific where a lot of this
plastic ends up floating
around and then back onto the
Lagoon so that was basically A Buddy
Story with a plastic bottle following
along so uh a lot of people remember the
plastic bottle anyway but we we really
talked about Marine debris and plastic
uh in the course of that one the third
story line I did about a year and a half
ago was probably my most difficult it
was on shark Finning I felt really
strongly about this uh issue and I felt
like since my main character was a shark
um the comic strip was a perfect vehicle
for telling the public about this now
Finning is the act of taking a shark uh
cutting the valuable fins off and
throwing the live animal back in the
water uh it's cruel it's wasteful
there's nothing funny or entertaining
about it but I really wanted to take
this issue on I had to kill my main
character who is a shark we start with
Sherman in the Chinese restaurant who
gets a fortune that he's about to get
caught by a trowler which he
does then he dies he gets finned and and
he gets thrown overboard ens he's dead
now and so I killed a character that
that's been in the newspaper for 15
years so I got a lot of reader feedback
on that one meanwhile the other
characters are talking about shark fin
soup I do three or four strips after
that where we explore the Finning issue
and the shark fin soup issue Sherman's
up in shark Heaven this is what I love
about comic strips you know you really
don't have to worry about the audience
dispending it a sense of uh disbelief
because if you start with a talking
shark readers pretty much check their
disbelief at the door you can kind of do
anything becomes a near-death experience
for Sherman meanwhile erest finds his
fins on the internet there was a real
website based in China that actually
sold shark fins so I kind of exposed
that and uh he clicks the buy now
button and voila Next Day Air they show
up and they surgically reattach them I
ended that series with a kind of a
mailin petition that encouraged our
National marine fisheries service to
force other countries to have a stronger
stance with shark
management
thanks I'd like to end with a little
metaphor here I've been trying to think
of a metaphor to represent Mission blue
and this is what I came up with um
imagine you're in an enormous room and
it's dark as a cave and you can have
anything in that room anything you want
but you can't see anything you've been
given one tool a
hammer so you wander around in the
darkness and you bump into something and
it feels like it's made of stone it's
big it's heavy you can't carry it away
so you bang it with your hammer and you
break off a piece and you take the piece
out into the
daylight and you see you have a
beautiful piece of white Alabaster so
you say to yourself well that's worth
something so you take a you go back into
the room and you break this thing to
pieces and you haul it away and you find
other things you break that up and You
Haul those away and you're getting all
kinds of cool stuff and you hear other
people doing the same thing so you get
this sense of urgency like you need to
find as much stuff as possible as soon
as possible and then somebody else stop
and they turn up the lights and you
realize where you are you're in the
lube and you've taken all this
complexity and
beauty and you've turned it into a cheap
commodity and that's what we're doing
with the ocean part of what mission blue
is
about is yelling
stop so that each of us Explorer
scientist cartoonist singer Chef can
turn the lights in our own way and
that's what I hope my comic strip does
in a small way that's what I like what I
do thanks for

listening the electric grid was
conceived in the age of Edison designed
in the age of Eisenhower installed in
the age of Nixon and it has not been
upgraded since it's just not able to
keep up with modern needs
well the notion of this SM Rd is using
what we have better making do with what
we've got and not build so much new
infrastructure software at the Gateway
between generation and transmission can
solve that problem a smart grid is
actually a bunch of smart devices
connected over a network to a bunch of
computers and computers crunch all this
data and then are able to optimize the
system what we're working on is helping
utilities see what's actually happening
in real time in terms of the flow of
electricity between all those devices
benefits the consumers benefits the
environment all because of things we can
now see that we couldn't see before on
the Olympic Peninsula pel's goal was to
make the smart grid tangible we were
taking home area networks as a way of
sending messages to the homes and to the
devices in the homes about when they
should run or not run
there was one other modem here that
captured wirelessly the reports from the
different elements we saved
approximately during this time 15% of
our electric bill if we can do that for
everybody in the country we're talking
about saving hundred billion dollar
worth of infrastructure that we won't
need to build IBM has been the first big
company to really see the opportunity to
marry Information Technology with the
grid there are similar things going on
in South America Asia in Europe we've
been working with Malta to make both the
water and electricity systems much more
efficient it is a model for how we can
then bring that to other larger
Geographic areas the path forward to a
Smart grid is actually quite clear we
upgraded our telecommunications networks
our satellite networks and we can do the
exact same thing uh with a smart grid a
wind plant will go up and down by the
minute a solar plant will go up and down
as clouds go over so having a grid that
can Flex itself and manage these these
kinds of things is critical we need to
be planning for the kind of future that
we say we want which is an air of cheap
reliable clean electricity for decades
to come
